newsTitle: LIVE MARKETS-European futures rise, lower deficit reports boost Italian bonds
body:
* European futures open higher
    * Dow clinched new record close
    * Euro rebounds from six-week lows
    * DAX closed for a holiday

    Oct 3 - Welcome to the home for real-time coverage of European equity markets brought to you
by Reuters stocks reporters and anchored today by Helen Reid. Reach her on Messenger to share
your thoughts on market moves: helen.reid.thomsonreuters.com@reuters.net     
 
 
    EUROPEAN FUTURES RISE, LOWER DEFICIT REPORTS BOOST ITALIAN BONDS (0617 GMT)
    European futures have started trading higher though only modestly - up 0.1 to 0.4 percent -
while the DAX is closed for a national holiday, so trading will likely be thinner than usual. 
    Part of the fuel for a rebound today could be reports that Italy's government is targeting a
lower budget deficit in 2020 and 2021. A government source just told us Italy is targeting a
budget deficit of 2.2 percent of GDP in 2020 and 2 percent of GDP in 2021, from the expected 2.4
percent next year. [nI6N1VP01Z]
    That's pushed Italian bond yields back down and narrowed the spread with German Bunds -
which will likely boost Italian bank stocks. 
    Italy's Prime Minister Conte is to meet with key ministers over the budget at around 1100
GMT on Wednesday, the source also said.
    "Italian budgetary issues are far from over," write Societe Generale analysts.
    "With little on the data or supply front for bond markets to focus on on Wednesday,
political headlines are likely to remain a key driver of the bond market near-term."
    (Helen Reid)
    *****

off a problematic debt blow-out. [nL4N1WJ0KQ]
    Also in political news, a blow for President Macron after interior minister and early ally
Gerard Collomb insisted he wanted to step down despite the president having rejected his
resignation less than 24 hours earlier. [nL8N1WI585]
    Opening calls from LCG are for the FTSE 100 to open 6 points higher at 7,481, the DAX to
open 11 points higher at 12,298, and the CAC 40 to open 8 points higher at 5,475.

newsTitle: LIVE MARKETS-What's on the radar: Tesco, Aston Martin, Topps Tiles
body:
* European futures open higher
    * Dow clinched new record close
    * Euro rebounds from six-week lows
    * DAX closed for a holiday

    Oct 3 - Welcome to the home for real-time coverage of European equity markets brought to you
by Reuters stocks reporters and anchored today by Helen Reid. Reach her on Messenger to share
your thoughts on market moves: helen.reid.thomsonreuters.com@reuters.net     
 
 
    
    WHAT'S ON THE RADAR: TESCO, ASTON MARTIN, TOPPS TILES (0646 GMT)
    European stocks are set to recover some of the previous day’s losses on Wednesday, with
futures trading up 0.1 to 0.4 percent, and risk appetite could be buoyed by the Dow clinching a
new record close in U.S. trading. 
    Italy will remain a focus for investors and its bank shares could see some relief after bond
yields fell back and the spread to Bunds narrowed thanks to reports the government was targeting
a lower budget deficit in 2020 and 2021. The DAX is closed for a holiday, thinning out trading
across Europe.
    In results Tesco reported a 24.4 percent rise in first-half profit, with results boosted by
the contribution from newly acquired wholesaler Booker and strong summer sales. But this wasn’t
enough to impress markets: the shares are indicated down around 2 percent as the profit figures
missed analysts’ estimates by 5 percent. 
    Also on investors’ radar is the IPO of Aston Martin on the London stock exchange. The luxury
carmaker priced its shares at 19 pounds each, giving it a valuation of $5.6 billion. 
    Surprisingly positive results from UK home improvement retailer Topps Tiles could drive the
shares up 3 to 5 percent, traders say. 
    The firm said it saw full-year profits above market expectations as trading in the fourth
quarter improved. It has been hit hard by consumers reducing big-ticket spending in the past two
years, and the stock is down 56 percent from its pre-Brexit vote levels.
    Tesco profit hit by weak sales in Europe and Asia [nL8N1WJ0T9]
    UK's Topps Tiles sees full-year profit above market expectations [nL4N1WJ17Q]
    Aston Martin priced at 19 pounds per share in float, eyes $5.6 bln valuation [nL8N1WJ0RE]
    UK's ITE sees higher full-year revenue, but warns of adverse currency movements [nL4N1WJ1BV]
    (Helen Reid)
    *****
    
    EUROPEAN FUTURES RISE, LOWER DEFICIT REPORTS BOOST ITALIAN BONDS (0617 GMT)
    European futures have started trading higher though only modestly - up 0.1 to 0.4 percent -
while the DAX is closed for a national holiday, so trading will likely be thinner than usual. 
    Part of the fuel for a rebound today could be reports that Italy's government is targeting a
lower budget deficit in 2020 and 2021. A government source just told us Italy is targeting a
budget deficit of 2.2 percent of GDP in 2020 and 2 percent of GDP in 2021, from the expected 2.4
percent next year. [nI6N1VP01Z]
    That's pushed Italian bond yields back down and narrowed the spread with German Bunds -
which will likely boost Italian bank stocks. 
    Italy's Prime Minister Conte is to meet with key ministers over the budget at around 1100
GMT on Wednesday, the source also said.
    "Italian budgetary issues are far from over," write Societe Generale analysts.
    "With little on the data or supply front for bond markets to focus on on Wednesday,
political headlines are likely to remain a key driver of the bond market near-term."
    (Helen Reid)

newsTitle: ECB may need to take bigger role to promote instant payments: Mersch
body:
RIGA, Oct 3 (Reuters) - Europe needs a wide-reaching, cheap
and instant retail payment system to stop overseas competitors
taking this market and the European Central Bank should consider
taking a bigger role in the field, ECB board member Yves Mersch
said on Wednesday.
    Instant payment systems are already in place from mobile
payment services to point-of-sale payments but most are limited
in their geographic reach, leaving PayPal and big American IT
firms dominating the market.
    "Payment service providers around Europe need to start
offering their customers instant payment services. And they need
to do so quickly," Mersch told a conference in Riga.
    "To promote euro area-wide, smooth and efficient payment
systems in line with our mandate, we might even have to reflect
on whether broader access to central bank accounts for retail
purposes may be needed," he added.
    Such a system would only work if it is truly pan-European,
instant, cheap and not restricted to a particular group of
clients, Mersch added.
    PayPal now dominates the European market for online payments
but players such as Google, Apple, Facebook, Amazon and Chinese
giants like Alibaba and Tencent are also taking market share.
    Mersch added that ultimately it will be the responsibility
of each service provider to gain the necessary size but noted
that the November launch of the ECB's instant payment system
between banks, called TARGET Instant Payment Settlement, could
provide a foundation.

 (Reporting by Gederts Gelzis
Writing by Balazs Koranyi
Editing by Andrew Heavens)
 ((Balazs.Koranyi@thomsonreuters.com; +49 69 7565 1244; Reuters
Messaging: balazs.koranyi.thomsonreuters.com@reuters.net))

newsTitle: Italian stocks, banks lead Europe as budget deficit fears quelled
body:
(For a live blog on European stocks, type LIVE/ in an Eikon
news window)
    LONDON, Oct 3 (Reuters) - Italian stocks turned from a drag
into a boost for European markets on Wednesday as signs the
government would target a lower budget deficit quelled
investors' fears of a damaging showdown with the European
Commission.
    Italian bank stocks <.FTIT8300> jumped 3.1 percent after
government bond yields fell back and the spread to Bunds
narrowed thanks to reports the government was targeting a lower
budget deficit in 2020 and 2021. [nL8N1WJ0NR]
    Still in the thrall of developments on the Italian front,
the leading euro zone stocks index <.STOXX50E> and the
pan-European STOXX 600 <.STOXX> both rose 0.3 percent by 0720
GMT, with bank stocks <.SX7P> the best-performing, up 1.1
percent.
    Italy's FTSE MIB <.FTMIB> outperformed, up 1.4 percent.
    Italy's biggest banks Unicredit <CRDI.MI> and Intesa
Sanpaolo <ISP.MI> were among the top gainers, up 2.6 percent
each, while Mediobanca <MDBI.MI>, UBI Banca <UBI.MI>, and Banco
BPM <BAMI.MI> also rose as much as 5 percent.
    Outside of politics, Oslo-listed aluminium firm Norsk Hydro
<NHY.OL> was the biggest faller, down 7.3 percent after
announcing it would shut all output from its Alunorte alumina
refinery in Brazil. [nFWN1WJ031]
    Tesco <TSCO.L> shares fell 5.5 percent after the UK's
biggest retailer reported first-half profits which missed
analysts' forecasts. [nL8N1WJ0T9]
    "Good like-for-like [sales], but weak bottom line points to
margin destruction," said a trader. 
    Shares in French tech consultancy Altran <ALTT.PA> jumped 11
percent to the top of the STOXX, with traders citing an upgrade
from broker Kepler Cheuvreux. 
    The stock, down 40 percent in the third quarter alone, is
highly shorted, amplifying any positive moves as short sellers
unwind their positions.  

 (Reporting by Helen Reid; editing by Danilo Masoni)
 ((mailto:Helen.Reid@thomsonreuters.com; +44 20 7542 0402;))

newsTitle: UPDATE 1-Italy's bond yields tumble on reports of lower deficits in 2020-2021
body:
* Italy targets deficit falling to 2.2 pct of GDP in 2020 
    * Bond yields fall, euro rallies on report
    * PM, ministers to discus budget later in session
    * Euro zone periphery govt bond yields http://tmsnrt.rs/2ii2Bqr

 (Updates with more detail, comment)
    By Dhara Ranasinghe
    LONDON, Oct 3 (Reuters) - Italian government bond yields
tumbled on Wednesday on reports that Rome plans to cut the
budget deficit faster than expected, easing fears about the
fiscal policy of the euro zone's third- biggest economy.
    Italy's government foresees the budget deficit falling to
2.2 percent of gross domestic product in 2020 and to 2 percent
in 2021 from the 2.4 percent expected next year, a government
source from the right-wing League party said on Wednesday
[nI6N1VP01Z].
    That bought relief to the bond market. It has taken a
beating since the coalition - of which the League is a member -
said last week it planned to run a deficit of 2.4 percent of GDP
over the next three years, tripling the previous target.
    Italian bond yields fell six to 19 basis points across the
board, after four days of sharp rises <IT2YT=RR> <IT5YT=RR>.    
     The 10-year Italian government bond yield fell 10 bps to
3.33 percent <IT10YT=RR>. It pulled back from the 4 1/2-year
high around 3.46 percent it reached on Tuesday, when comments
from a lawmaker about Italy's position in the euro bloc fuelled
a selloff. 
     Wednesday's fall in Italian yields left the gap over
benchmark German bond yields <DE10YT=RR>, a closely followed
indicator of relative country risks, at 290 bps -- down from
around 300 bps late Tuesday.
    "The deficit forecast news is main reason markets are doing
what they are doing today," said KBC rates strategist Mathias
van der Jeugt.
    "But this is too little to bridge the gap between the EU and
Italy. We might get some more relief, but I think it will be
short-lived unless Italy comes up with a better proposal that is
more aligned with what the EU wants."
    EU Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker drew parallels
on Monday between Italy's budget plans and the finances of
Greece, which only emerged from its third international bailout
in August [nL8N1WI4KW]. 
    Italian Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte is due to meet with
ministers to discuss the budget targets for 2019-2021 at around
1100 GMT on Wednesday, a source told Reuters.
    The 2020-2021 deficit numbers were first reported by the
newspapers Corriere della Sera and La Repubblica, lifting the
euro <EUR=> during Asian trade [nL4N1WJ0I0]. 
    The euro was last up 0.3 percent against the dollar. Italian
shares rose 1.3 percent <.FTMIB>, outperforming European stocks
overall <.STOXX>.
    As Italy's bond market rebounded, yields on higher-rated
euro zone bonds rose. Germany's 10-year Bund yield was up three
bps at 0.46 percent.
    "The (Italian) situation remains fluid and mood can make
sudden U-turns, depending on a rather unpredictable news flow,"
analysts at UniCredit said in a note.

    <^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
Italy's 2-year bond yield: absolute change    https://reut.rs/2QqI0NN
    ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^>
 (Reporting by Dhara Ranasinghe, editing by Larry King)
 ((Dhara.Ranasinghe@thomsonreuters.com; +442075422684;))

newsTitle: BREAKINGVIEWS-Fiat car-parts sale needs private equity mechanics
body:
(The author is a Reuters Breakingviews columnist.  The opinions
expressed are his own.)
    By Liam Proud
    LONDON, Oct 3 (Reuters Breakingviews) - The carmaker may
spin off or sell its Magneti Marelli unit. Handing it to
shareholders would let them keep any upside. But the outlook for
parts makers is mixed, and valuations low. Selling to the likes
of KKR makes more sense, even if CEO Mike Manley has to accept a
price cut.
        
    Full view will be published shortly.
    On Twitter https://twitter.com/liamwardproud
        
    CONTEXT NEWS
    - Calsonic Kansei has lined up around 5 billion euros in
financing from Japanese banks to fund its proposed acquisition
of Fiat Chrysler's unit Magneti Marelli, Reuters reported on
Sept. 21 citing four sources familiar with the matter. 
    - The Japanese car-parts maker, owned by U.S. private equity
group KKR, has been in talks with Fiat Chrysler (FCA) for months
and made an initial proposal of 5.8 billion euros for Magneti
Marelli, according to Reuters. 
    - FCA is seeking more than 6 billion euros for the
diversified parts maker, which specialises in lighting,
powertrain and electronics. 
    - FCA is evaluating other buyers for Marelli after KKR
offered less than its desired 6 billion euro price, Bloomberg
reported on Sept. 16 citing people familiar with the matter. 
    - For previous columns by the author, Reuters customers can
click on [PROUD/]
    - SIGN UP FOR BREAKINGVIEWS EMAIL ALERTS http://bit.ly/BVsubscribe

newsTitle: UBS Wealth says two-year Italian bonds now attractive after  selloff
body:
LONDON, Oct 3 (Reuters) - UBS Wealth on Wednesday updated
its investment recommendation on two-year Italian government
bonds to overweight, following a budget related selloff in the
country's debt. 
    Italian two-year government bond yields have risen around 50
basis points in the past week, after the country's government
revealed on Thursday a higher-than-anticipated budget deficit of
2.4 percent for 2019. 
    But short-dated bonds now look attractive versus cash, UBS
Wealth said in a note, adding that two-year yields offered
around 160 basis points over comparably rated euro-denominated
bonds. 
    "While we believe that Italy's credit rating is likely to be
downgraded by one notch, the country is likely to retain an
investment grade rating for at least the next 12 months, and we
believe there is only a very low probability that Italy will
default within the next two years," Mark Haefele, global chief
investment officer at UBS Wealth, said in the note. 
    However, UBS Wealth cautioned against holding long-dated
Italian bonds, and advised against any concentrated exposure to
them. 
    It noted possible risks associated with the position,
including escalating tensions between Italy and the European
Union over the budget, a breakdown of the current coalition
government, or a departure of Finance Minister Giovanni Tria. 

 (Reporting by Virginia Furness, editing by Dhara Ranasinghe)
 ((Dhara.Ranasinghe@thomsonreuters.com; +442075422684;))

newsTitle: Euro zone business growth eases in Sept to a 4-month low - PMI
body:
- PMI points to Q3 GDP growth of 0.5 pct -IHS Markit
    

    By Rahul Karunakar
    Oct 3 (Reuters) - The expansion in euro zone business activity eased in September to a four-month low, driven by the weakest factory growth in two years that was only partly offset by a pick-up among services providers, a survey showed on Wednesday.
    IHS Markit's Euro Zone Composite Final Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI), seen as a good guide to economic health, eased to a four month-low in September of 54.1 from August's 54.5.
    That was below an earlier flash estimate of 54.2, but held well above the 50 mark which separates growth from contraction.
    Optimism about the future brightened a bit at the end of the third quarter from a near-two-year low. The composite future output PMI rose to 62.1 from  61.6.
    But manufacturing activity has dwindled across the euro currency bloc this year, in line with evidence of moderation elsewhere around the globe.
    That suggests overall economic growth in the currency bloc is well past its peak and the pace of business activity is likely to ease further in coming months.
    "Although running close to a two-year low, the disappointing September PMI remains at a relatively elevated level and signals solid growth," noted Chris Williamson, chief business economist at IHS Markit.
    "However, the fourth quarter is unlikely to see such robust growth, as recent months have seen a clear loss of momentum in terms of both output and new order gains."
    The surveys point to quarterly euro zone economic growth of 0.5 percent. That is slightly higher than a 0.4 percent consensus in a recent Reuters poll of economists, who unanimously said that the U.S.-China trade war threatened the already modest outlook. [ECILT/EU]
    Manufacturers are increasingly concerned about barriers to global trade, which was clear from the readings of forward-looking factory PMI survey indicators. Growth in new export orders eased to the lowest in more than five years. [nL9N1S702B]
    The latest surveys show a clear divergence between performance by euro zone services and manufacturing firms.
    Services activity picked up to the highest in three months, as measured by the final services PMI at 54.7, which matched the  flash reading but was higher than 54.4 in August.
    Services firms hired at a slightly faster pace than in August, too. The employment sub-index rose to 55.5, not seen since October 2007, during boom times before the last financial crisis. It was 55.3 in August.
    "While employment gains remained historically high, a steady erosion in the rate of order book growth so far this year suggest the appetite to hire will soon wane without any notable upturn in new order inflows," added Williamson.
    "With business confidence about the outlook running at one of the lowest seen over the past two years, companies are clearly not expecting any such imminent turn-around in demand."
    
    - Detailed PMI data are only available under licence from IHS Markit and customers need to apply for a licence.
    To subscribe to the full data, click on the link below: https://www.ihsmarkit.com/about/contact-us.html
    For further information, please phone IHS Markit on +800 6275 4800 or email economics@ihsmarkit.com 

 (Reporting by Rahul Karunakar; Editing by Hugh Lawson)
 ((rahul.karunakar@thomsonreuters.com; +91 80 67496115; Reuters Messaging: rahul.karunakar.thomsonreuters.com@reuters.net))

Keywords: EUROZONE ECONOMY/PMI

newsTitle: BREAKINGVIEWS-Fiat car-parts sale needs private equity mechanics
body:
(The author is a Reuters Breakingviews columnist.  The opinions
expressed are his own.)
    By Liam Proud
    LONDON, Oct 3 (Reuters Breakingviews) - Former Fiat Chrysler
<FCHA.MI> <FCAU.N> boss Sergio Marchionne was a master of
spinoffs. The Ferrari <RACE.MI> and industrial businesses he
handed over to shareholders are now worth 50 percent more than
the carmaker itself. Yet new boss Mike Manley may find a quick
and dirty sale is best for auto supplier Magneti Marelli. 
    Fiat is mulling two options for the maker of headlights,
exhaust systems and electrical gizmos: list it and distribute
shares to Fiat investors, or sell to a third party, most likely
a private equity fund. Manley had lined up Calsonic Kansei, a
parts maker owned by KKR <KKR.N>, as a preferred bidder, but is
now courting others after KKR’s offers fell short of
expectations. Fiat Chairman John Elkann wants an enterprise
value of at least 6 billion euros, according to a person
familiar with the matter.
    A spinoff would probably create value. Including debt,
listed peers Hella <HLE.DE>, Valeo <VLOF.PA> and Faurecia
<EPED.PA> are valued at an average of 7.2 times 2018 operating
profit, according to Eikon. That’s over twice Fiat’s multiple of
3.2. As well as receiving shares in a more highly-rated company,
investors could keep any upside from future growth.
    The snag is that car suppliers are in a funk. Thomson
Reuters’ Auto, Truck and Motorcycle Parts Index has fallen 26
percent this year as investors fretted about trade wars and a
profit warning from industry bellwether Continental.  
    And Magneti Marelli faces longer-term pressures. Its revenue
growth has slowed from 11.7 percent in 2015 to 7.4 percent last
year, according to Evercore analysts, who expect growth to fall
to just 3 percent in 2019. Its “powertrain” or engine-systems
business, which makes up 15 percent of revenue, may shrink as
consumers switch to electric vehicles. Fiat investors risk
getting stuck with discounted shares in a slow-growing business.
    That would make private equity’s bag of cash look
attractive. KKR has lined up Japanese banks to provide 5 billion
euros of funding for its bid, Reuters reported. Even an offer at
that price would still be a 30 percent premium to Marelli’s
value including debt of 3.9 billion euros on listed peer
multiples. And investors would get their hands on the money
right away, rather than having to wait for a takeover or for
supplier valuations to recover. It’s worth breaking with Fiat’s
esteemed tradition of spinoffs.        
    On Twitter https://twitter.com/liamwardproud
        
    CONTEXT NEWS
    - Calsonic Kansei has lined up around 5 billion euros in
financing from Japanese banks to fund its proposed acquisition
of Fiat Chrysler's unit Magneti Marelli, Reuters reported on
Sept. 21 citing four sources familiar with the matter. 
    - The Japanese car-parts maker, owned by U.S. private equity
group KKR, has been in talks with Fiat Chrysler (FCA) for months
and made an initial proposal of 5.8 billion euros for Magneti
Marelli, according to Reuters. 
    - FCA is seeking more than 6 billion euros for the
diversified parts maker, which specialises in lighting,
powertrain and electronics. 
    - FCA is evaluating other buyers for Marelli after KKR
offered less than its desired 6 billion euro price, Bloomberg
reported on Sept. 16 citing people familiar with the matter. 
    - For previous columns by the author, Reuters customers can
click on [PROUD/]
    - SIGN UP FOR BREAKINGVIEWS EMAIL ALERTS http://bit.ly/BVsubscribe

    <^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
KKR-backed Calsonic lines up 5 bln euro financing for Magneti
takeover - sources    [nL8N1W7400]
Bloomberg article    https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-09-16/fiat-is-said-to-weigh-new-marelli-approaches-after-low-kkr-bid
BREAKINGVIEWS-China problems could be the making of new FCA boss
   [nL1N1UL0HX]
BREAKINGVIEWS-How Sergio Marchionne saved Fiat and Chrysler   
[nL1N1UQ0UR]

   [nL5N1UL1WH]

 (Editing by Neil Unmack and Bob Cervi)

liam.ward-proud.thomsonreuters.com@reuters.net))

newsTitle: Fitch Ratings: Car RV Shock Would Hit Profits, Capital Impact Manageable
body:
(The following statement was released by the rating agency)


Link to Fitch Ratings' Report(s): European Car Financing Vulnerable to Residual 
Value Outlook 

https://www.fitchratings.com/site/re/10045729

Fitch Ratings-London-October 03: German auto makers' financing arms would see 
profitability fall sharply if there were a large, sudden decline in second-hand 
car prices, Fitch Ratings says. European lease-focused banks' capital would drop 
significantly, but remain above regulatory minimums. But large, diversified 
banks would see little impact, even if they have large vehicle leasing 
businesses. 

Vehicle financing has supported new vehicle registrations in Europe in recent 
years. Operating leases, where the lessor retains ownership of the vehicle, have 
accounted for an increasing proportion of financing, particularly in Germany and 
the UK, the largest markets for new cars. In the wake of emissions-test cheating 
scandals, and a fear of a glut in second-hand cars, this exposes the lessor to 
residual value (RV) risk - the risk that second-hand car prices will fall below 
the estimate at the inception of the lease. 

To test resilience to RV risk, we used a hypothetical scenario involving a 20% 
fall in second-hand prices and a 100% turn-in rate, translating into a 5% "shock 
depreciation" on the entire operational lease portfolio of major captives, banks 
and non-bank financial institutions (NBFIs) as at end-2017. This scenario, which 
is much harsher than our RV assumptions, results in EUR9.5 billion of extra 
impairments on EUR190 billion of RVs. 

More than half of these impairments (EUR5.4 billion) would be at German 
captives, reducing profitability by over 80%, due to their concentrated 
portfolios. However, assuming impairments were spread out over three years, 
consistent with typical 'straight-line' depreciation policies on operational 
leases, rather than a one-off hit, impairments would typically be around a 
quarter of divisional profits before taxes. 

Depletion of lease banks' CET1 ratios would range between 0.1% and 5.3% in a 
one-off shock, but would remain well above regulatory minimums. Large European 
banks with significant vehicle leasing portfolios have bigger and more 
diversified balance sheets and would largely shrug off the low (10bp-23bp) CET1 
ratio impact. 

Mitigants to an unexpected RV shock include the likelihood that manufacturers 
would provide support to captives, both directly (through financial guarantees) 
and indirectly (for example by adjusting pricing to regulate vehicle 
inventories). Both captives and financing NBFIs may get volume discounts from 
manufacturers when buying new vehicles in bulk, giving them some additional 
headroom for RV declines. 

Leading lessors have sophisticated pricing and risk systems, including 
monitoring and forecasting used car prices. These will be influenced in the long 
term by innovations such as ride-hailing schemes and autonomous vehicles, 
although we believe the impact of electrification on RVs will be visible 
earlier. 

Our report 'Car Financing Vulnerable to Residual Value Outlook' was published 
today and is available at www.fitchratings.com or by clicking on the link.

Contact: 

Monsur Hussain

Senior Director, Financial Institutions - Research

+44 20 3530 1793

Fitch Ratings Limited

30 North Colonnade

London E14 5GN

Mark Young

Managing Director, Financial Institutions - Non-Banks

+44 20 3530 1318

Andy Brewer

Senior Director, Structured Finance

+44 20 3530 1005

Mark Brown

Senior Analyst, Fitch Wire

+44 20 3530 1588

Media Relations: Peter Fitzpatrick, London, Tel: +44 20 3530 1103, Email: 
peter.fitzpatrick@fitchratings.com.

The above article originally appeared as a post on the Fitch Wire credit market 
commentary page. The original article can be accessed at www.fitchratings.com. 
All opinions expressed are those of Fitch Ratings.

PLEASE READ THESE LIMITATIONS AND DISCLAIMERS BY FOLLOWING THIS LINK:

newsTitle: UPDATE 1-Italian stocks lead Europe as budget deficit fears quelled
body:
* Italy's FTSE MIB up 0.8 pct, banks up 1.2 pct
    * Norsk Hydro sinks 13 pct on Brazil mine closure
    * Altran jumps 9 pct on Kepler upgrade to "buy"
    * Grifols hit by UBS downgrade to "sell"

 (Updates prices, adds quotes, details)
    By Helen Reid
    LONDON, Oct 3 (Reuters) - Italian stocks turned from a drag
into a boost for European markets on Wednesday as signs the
government would target a lower budget deficit quelled
investors' fears of a damaging showdown with the European
Commission.
    Italian bank stocks <.FTIT8300> jumped as much as 3 percent
after government bond yields fell back and the spread to Bunds
narrowed thanks to reports the government was targeting a lower
budget deficit in 2020 and 2021. [nL8N1WJ0NR]
    Still in the thrall of developments on the Italian front,
the leading euro zone stocks index <.STOXX50E> and the
pan-European STOXX 600 <.STOXX> climbed 0.3 percent with bank
stocks <.SX7P> the best-performing, up 0.8 percent.
    Italy's FTSE MIB <.FTMIB> outperformed, up 0.5 percent with
the banks index last trading up 0.7 percent.
    Unicredit <CRDI.MI> and Intesa Sanpaolo <ISP.MI> were among
the top gainers, up 2.6 percent each, while Mediobanca
<MDBI.MI>, UBI Banca <UBI.MI>, and Banco BPM <BAMI.MI> also rose
as much as 5 percent.
    Banks, which have large sovereign bond holdings, suffer the
most from selloffs in the bond market and the index saw its
fifth consecutive day down on Tuesday before news the government
was aiming for a lower budget deficit.
    "Any indication from the government that may deny such
indications and lead to a step up in confrontation will
negatively affect BTP spreads," said Unicredit analysts.
    "The situation remains fluid and mood can make sudden
U-turns, depending on a rather unpredictable news flow."
    Outside politics, Oslo-listed aluminium firm Norsk Hydro
<NHY.OL> was the biggest faller, tumbling 13.6 percent after
announcing it would shut all output from its Alunorte alumina
refinery in Brazil. [nFWN1WJ031]
    "This is a very serious event for Norsk Hydro, potentially
leading to severe losses," said a trader.
    Grifols <GRLS.MC> shares fell 6 percent after UBS analysts
cut the stock to sell from neutral, saying competitive risks are
rising.
    "Fc Rn inhibitors, a new class of drug we expect to launch
in 2021, threaten to replace up to 20 percent of Grifols sales,"
said analysts at the Swiss bank. 
    Tesco <TSCO.L> shares fell 8.5 percent after Britain's
biggest retailer reported first-half profits which missed
analysts' forecasts. [nL8N1WJ0T9]
    "Good like-for-like (sales), but weak bottom line points to
margin destruction," said a trader. 
    Shares in French tech consultancy Altran <ALTT.PA> jumped 9
percent to 8.12 euros, at the top of the STOXX after Kepler
Cheuvreux analysts upgraded the stock to "buy" from "hold" with
a price target of 10 euros.
    Kepler analysts said they see no risk for liquidity, and
that Altran's current share price values its global design and
engineering company Aricent at roughly 0. 
    The stock, down 40 percent in the third quarter alone, is a
popular short, amplifying any positive moves as short-sellers
unwind their positions.  

    <^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
Italian stocks lag Europe    https://reut.rs/2QpHsbe
    ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^>
 (Reporting by Helen Reid; Editing by Danilo Masoni and Andrew
Heavens)
 ((mailto:Helen.Reid@thomsonreuters.com; +44 20 7542 0402;))

newsTitle: BREAKINGVIEWS-Italy’s 5G auction is an $8 billion smash-and-grab
body:
(The author is a Reuters Breakingviews columnist.  The opinions
expressed are his own.)
    By Liam Proud
    LONDON, Oct 3 (Reuters Breakingviews) - The cash-strapped
country raised more money than expected thanks to the canny way
it sold mobile spectrum. The consequences are for others. If
operators raise prices, it’s effectively a stealth tax. If they
can’t, there will be less cash to build new networks in Europe.
        
    Full view will be published shortly.
    On Twitter https://twitter.com/liamwardproud
    
    CONTEXT NEWS
    - Italy said on Oct. 2 that its auction of fifth-generation
(5G) mobile spectrum raised 6.55 billion euros, or 164 percent
more than the value of initial offers.
    - Debt-heavy Telecom Italia spent 2.41 billion euros, and
said it expected to pay out around 480 million euros of the
overall amount in 2018. 
    - Vodafone Italy bought airwaves in three frequency ranges
for a total of 2.4 billion euros. It said some of the spectrum
could be immediately used to enhance coverage and improve
capacity.
    - France’s Iliad paid about 1.2 billion euros, while Wind
Tre paid just over 500 million euros. Fastweb, a broadband and
landline company, bought a small block of spectrum for roughly
33 million euros. 
    - Telecom Italia and Vodafone shares were up 0.6 percent and
1.3 percent respectively at 0810 GMT on Oct. 3. Iliad rose 0.7
percent and CK Hutchison – the holding company of Wind Tre’s
Hong Kong-based parent – was down almost 1 percent.
    - For previous columns by the author, Reuters customers can
click on [PROUD/]
    - SIGN UP FOR BREAKINGVIEWS EMAIL ALERTS http://bit.ly/BVsubscribe

    <^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

   [nL8N1K238I]

   [nL4N1L332X]

newsTitle: Web Summit to stay in Lisbon for 10 years - CEO
body:
LISBON, Oct 3 (Reuters) - Europe's largest tech event, the
Web Summit, will remain in Lisbon for another 10 years, its
founder Paddy Cosgrave said on Wednesday in a big boost to
Portugal's aspirations of becoming a technology hub.
    "Staying here for another 10 years brings us so much
certainty," Cosgrave told journalists at a press conference
where he was joined by Portuguese Prime Minister Antonio Costa.
    Web Summit moved to Lisbon from Dublin in 2016 and the event
will be held for the third time in the city in November. The
original contract envisioned three years in Lisbon and the Web
Summit organizers had considered moving to other venues in
Europe before deciding to stay.
    

 (Reporting By Catarina Demony, writing by Axel Bugge)
 ((axel.bugge@thomsonreuters.com; +351-213-509-201; Reuters
Messaging: axel.bugge.thomsonreuters.com@reuters.net))

newsTitle: Brexit talks must focus on divorce deal before future ties - Czech official
body:
BRUSSELS, Oct 3 (Reuters) - Britain and the European Union
must focus on getting a divorce deal with an emergency Irish
border fix before they embark on discussions on their
post-Brexit trade ties, the Czech Republic's pointman on Europe
said. 
    Britain is due to leave the EU in 177 days but talks on
managing the unprecedented split have stalled over differences
on how to avoid border checks between EU member Ireland and
Britain's province of Northern Ireland afterwards.
    Eyes are on British Prime Minister Theresa May's final
speech at her Tory Party conference on Wednesday. [nL8N1WI5PB] A
flurry of activity will follow as both sides seek to try to
break the deadlock in time for EU summits on Oct.18 and
Nov.17-18 at the latest. [nL8N1WI4Y0]
    "The chief concern for the EU right now is reaching a deal
on the Withdrawal Agreement that would provide us with a two
year transition period in which to set out the future
relationship between the EU and the UK," State Secretary for
European Affairs Ales Chmelar said in a comment to Reuters,
adding that divorce must cover an Irish fix. 
    That differs from Britain's preferred option of focusing on
agreeing close future ties in trade. London wants this
post-Brexit arrangement to regulate the Irish border but the
bloc wants an emergency solution if trade talks fail or take
longer.
    "The future relationship ... is a matter for future
discussions. Without the Withdrawal Agreement we are, very soon,
heading towards a no deal scenario in which a hard border would
inevitably be drawn up," Chmelar said. 
    As both sides ready concessions in the coming days, Britain
is expected to present a new proposal for the Irish border soon.
    From the EU side, the other 27 member states will put in
writing for the first time next week their free trade proposal
for Britain for after Brexit, hoping a more fleshed-out promise
would woo London into compromises on Ireland and help May get
enough support behind any divorce deal. 

 (Reporting by Gabriela Baczynska
Editing by Richard Balmforth)
 ((gabriela.baczynska@thomsonreuters.com; +32 2 287 68 39;
Reuters Messaging:
gabriela.baczynska.thomsonreuters.com@reuters.net))

newsTitle: Spain should cut debt and preserve labour reforms to resist economic shocks - IMF
body:
MADRID, Oct 3 (Reuters) - Spain should rein in its debt and
deficit and maintain labour market reforms to resist future
shocks as downside risks to the economy build, the International
Monetary Fund (IMF) said on Wednesday.
    The IMF trimmed its forecast for 2018 growth in the euro
zone's fourth-largest economy to 2.7 percent, in line with the
Socialist government's expectations, from the 2.8 percent
forecast it made in April.
    The Spanish economy is showing signs of flagging after 19
consecutive quarters of growth, but is still on track to remain
among the fastest growing in Europe. [nL5N1VR5MP]

 (Reporting by Isla Binnie
Editing by Jesus Aguado)
 ((isla.binnie@thomsonreuters.com; +39 06 8522 4392; Reuters
Messaging: isla.binnie.thomsonreuters.com@reuters.net))

newsTitle: LIVE MARKETS-Reasons to be cheerful about European stocks
body:
* European shares open higher
    * Dow clinched new record close
    * Euro rebounds from six-week lows
    * DAX closed for a holiday

    Oct 3 - Welcome to the home for real-time coverage of European equity markets brought to you
by Reuters stocks reporters and anchored today by Helen Reid. Reach her on Messenger to share
your thoughts on market moves: helen.reid.thomsonreuters.com@reuters.net     
 
    
    
    REASONS TO BE CHEERFUL ABOUT EUROPEAN STOCKS (1002 GMT)
    There's growing evidence the trade war is hurting global economic activity, and European
stocks remain in thrall of politics, but Barclays analysts still find reasons to be cheerful. 
    "Positioning on Europe appears to be particularly bearish and it is the only region to have
seen net outflows year-to-date," they note, but they see positives outweighing the negatives and
expect "modest upside" into the end of the year. 
    Fundamentals are supportive overall, they maintain. Here are their reasons to be cheerful: 
    * Global growth should be resilient in 2018 at around 4%
    * Earnings revisions are on the right track
    * P/E multiples have fallen 
    * Investors have derisked and sentiment is cautious, but Q4 is typically more positive
    * FX is turning into a support again for the euro zone and UK

    As you can see below, after cyclicals underperformed over Q3, they've started coming back
again as the Citi economic surprise indicator for the euro zone bottomed out. 
    Barclays back cyclical stocks and have a couple of pretty contrarian calls including
overweight financials and autos - but on the big issue of the day, Italy, they remain negative:
"We expect Italy to enter a prolonged period of volatility, which is unlikely to help  European
markets". 
 
    (Helen Reid)
    *****
    
    OPENING SNAPSHOT: ITALIAN RELIEF HELPS EUROPE BOUNCE BACK (0727 GMT)
    Reports that the Italian government aims to lower its budget deficit in 2020 and 2021 from
the 2.4 percent targeted for next year [nI6N1VP01Z] is spreading some optimism among investors,
helping European and Italian stocks rebound after a turbulent start of the week.
    The STOXX 600 <.STOXX> is rising 0.3 percent and Italy's FTSE MIB is bouncing up more than 1
percent and almost all sectors are trading in the black. Activity was reduced by the closure of
the DAX.    
 
    (Danilo Masoni)
    *****
    
    WHAT'S ON THE RADAR: TESCO, ASTON MARTIN, TOPPS TILES (0646 GMT)
    European stocks are set to recover some of the previous day’s losses on Wednesday, with
futures trading up 0.1 to 0.4 percent, and risk appetite could be buoyed by the Dow clinching a
new record close in U.S. trading. 
    Italy will remain a focus for investors and its bank shares could see some relief after bond
yields fell back and the spread to Bunds narrowed thanks to reports the government was targeting
a lower budget deficit in 2020 and 2021. The DAX is closed for a holiday, thinning out trading
across Europe.
    In results Tesco reported a 24.4 percent rise in first-half profit, with results boosted by
the contribution from newly acquired wholesaler Booker and strong summer sales. But this wasn’t
enough to impress markets: the shares are indicated down around 2 percent as the profit figures
missed analysts’ estimates by 5 percent. 
    Also on investors’ radar is the IPO of Aston Martin on the London stock exchange. The luxury
carmaker priced its shares at 19 pounds each, giving it a valuation of $5.6 billion. 
    Surprisingly positive results from UK home improvement retailer Topps Tiles could drive the
shares up 3 to 5 percent, traders say. 
    The firm said it saw full-year profits above market expectations as trading in the fourth
quarter improved. It has been hit hard by consumers reducing big-ticket spending in the past two
years, and the stock is down 56 percent from its pre-Brexit vote levels.
    Tesco profit hit by weak sales in Europe and Asia [nL8N1WJ0T9]

GMT on Wednesday, the source also said.

newsTitle: UPDATE 1-Web Summit to stay in Lisbon for 10 years -CEO
body:
(Updates with PM quotes, details)
    LISBON, Oct 3 (Reuters) - Europe's largest tech event, the
Web Summit, will remain in Lisbon for another 10 years, its
founder Paddy Cosgrave said on Wednesday in a boost to
Portugal's aspirations of becoming a technology hub.
    "Staying here for another 10 years brings us so much
certainty," Cosgrave told journalists at a press conference
where he was joined by Portuguese Prime Minister Antonio Costa.
"My heart and the team's heart is in Lisbon."
    Lisbon scored a big coup when Web Summit moved from Dublin
to Portugal in 2016, helping a recovery in the country's capital
after the 2011-2014 debt crisis. 
    Web Summit has helped put Lisbon on the map and drive a
tourist boom, as well as attract technology firms to the city.
    "It's a pleasure to host Web Summit in Portugal for the next
10 years," Costa said. "It puts Portugal at the heart of the
global conversation about tech and innovation."
    The government estimates that the event itself generates 300
million euros ($347 million) for Lisbon in hotel and other
revenue during the week it takes place in November.
    Around 70,000 people attended the Web Summit last year and
the organisers hope to boost that to 100,000. 
    The original Web Summit contract envisioned three years in
Lisbon and the Web Summit organizers had considered moving to
other venues in Europe before deciding to stay. 
    The event is held in the pavilions built for Lisbon's 1998
World Fair and one of the reasons the organizers decided to stay
is because it can expand further in that area.
    ($1 = 0.8646 euros)

 (Reporting By Catarina Demony, writing by Axel Bugge, editing
by Andrei Khalip and David Evans)
 ((axel.bugge@thomsonreuters.com; +351-213-509-201; Reuters
Messaging: axel.bugge.thomsonreuters.com@reuters.net))

newsTitle: UPDATE 1-Spain should cut debt and preserve labour reforms to resist economic shocks - IMF
body:
(Adds detail, quotes)
    MADRID, Oct 3 (Reuters) - Spain should rein in its debt and
deficit and maintain labour market reforms to resist future
shocks as downside risks to the economy build, the International
Monetary Fund (IMF) said on Wednesday.
    The IMF trimmed its forecast for 2018 growth in the euro
zone's fourth-largest economy to 2.7 percent, in line with the
Socialist government's expectations, from the 2.8 percent
forecast it made in April.
    The Spanish economy is showing signs of flagging after 19
consecutive quarters of growth, but is still on track to remain
among the fastest growing in Europe. [nL5N1VR5MP]    
    "At this juncture, it is critical to strengthen the
economy's resilience to withstand shocks," the IMF said in the
concluding statement of its 2018 report on Spain. 
    "Two policy areas are key for this goal: restarting
structural fiscal adjustment and preserving the thrust of the
labour market reforms" introduced by the previous conservative
government, it added.
    Debt levels have only come down marginally while the economy
has grown strongly, making the government's aim to cut the
deficit to 1.8 percent of GDP for 2019 "critical and
appropriate", the IMF said. 
    It urged the government to preserve the thrust of the 2012
labour market reform, which included wage flexibility that "has
underpinned Spain's job-rich economic recovery and regained
competitiveness".   
    A sustainable and comprehensive pension package is also
needed to address current tensions in the system, the IMF said.

 (Reporting by Isla Binnie; Editing by Toby Chopra)
 ((isla.binnie@thomsonreuters.com; +39 06 8522 4392; Reuters
Messaging: isla.binnie.thomsonreuters.com@reuters.net))

newsTitle: Trade Bank of Iraq signs 100 million euro loan agreement with Commerzbank
body:
DUBAI, Oct 3 (Reuters) - Trade Bank of Iraq (TBI), a
government owned lender, has signed a loan agreement with
Commerzbank <CBKG.DE> to support small and medium sized
enterprises in Iraq.
    TBI aims to back public and private sector projects worth up
to 100 million euros ($115 million) in business volume, it said
in a statement.
    The focus of the financing partnership will be on export
contracts awarded to clients of Commerzbank in Germany and other
European countries.
    
    ($1 = 0.8651 euros)

 (Reporting by Davide Barbuscia; Editing by Toby Chopra)
 ((Davide.Barbuscia@thomsonreuters.com; +971522604297; Reuters
Messaging: davide.barbuscia.reuters.com@reuters.net))

newsTitle: UPDATE 2-Italy's bond yields fall after Rome says to cut deficit from 2020
body:
* Italy targets deficit falling to 2.2 pct of GDP in 2020 
    * Bond yields fall, euro rallies on report
    * PM, ministers to discus budget later in session
    * Euro zone periphery govt bond yields http://tmsnrt.rs/2ii2Bqr

 (Updates with latest headlines, price action, adds comment)
    By Dhara Ranasinghe
    LONDON, Oct 3 (Reuters) - Italy's government bond yields
fell on Wednesday on reports that Rome plans to cut the budget
deficit faster than it had previously indicated, easing fears
about the fiscal policy of the euro zone's third- biggest
economy.
    Rome foresees the budget deficit falling to 2.2 percent of
gross domestic product in 2020 and to 2 percent in 2021 from the
2.4 percent expected next year, a government source from the
right-wing League said on Wednesday [nI6N1VP01Z].    
    That bought relief to the bond market, the euro and stocks. 
    Later in the session, Economy Minister Giovanni Tria
appeared to confirm the source-based report, saying Italy's
budget deficit will fall gradually from 2020 [nR1N1VZ00T].
    Debt markets, in particular, have taken a beating since the
coalition government - of which the League is a member - said
last week it planned to run a deficit of 2.4 percent of GDP over
the next three years, tripling the previous target.
    Italian borrowing costs were broadly lower on Wednesday
after four days of sharp rises <IT2YT=RR> <IT5YT=RR>, but off
lows hit in early trade, as a note of caution crept back in. 
     The 10-year Italian government bond yield was down 4 bps at
3.39 percent <IT10YT=RR>, below Tuesday's 4 1/2-year high around
3.46 percent. 
    That left the gap over benchmark German bond yields
<DE10YT=RR>, a closely followed indicator of relative country
risks, at 295 bps versus 300 bps late Tuesday.
    "The deficit forecast news is main reason markets are doing
what they are doing today," said KBC rates strategist Mathias
van der Jeugt.
    "But this is too little to bridge the gap between the EU and
Italy. We might get some more relief, but I think it will be
short-lived unless Italy comes up with a better proposal that is
more aligned with what the EU wants."
    EU Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker drew parallels
on Monday between Italy's budget plans and the finances of
Greece, which only emerged from its third international bailout
in August [nL8N1WI4KW]. 
    Italian Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte is due to meet with
ministers to discuss the budget targets for 2019-2021 at around
1100 GMT on Wednesday, a source told Reuters.
    "Let's not forget the yield is pretty high, so there is a
carry element as well, so people latch on to any newsflow that
may be coming through," said Salman Ahmed, chief investment
strategist at Lombard Odier Investment Managers, referring to
the recovery in Italian bonds. 
    UBS Wealth said that it now saw two-year Italian bonds as
attractive after the heavy selloff [nL8N1WJ1CP].
    The euro <EUR=> and stocks also benefited from the more
positive noises coming from Rome. Italian shares rose 0.85
percent <.FTMIB>, outperforming European stocks overall
<.STOXX>.    
    As Italy's bond market rebounded, yields on higher-rated
euro zone bonds rose. Germany's 10-year Bund yield was up 1.5
bps at 0.44 percent.

    <^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
Italy's 2-year bond yield: absolute change    https://reut.rs/2QqI0NN
    ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^>
 (Reporting by Dhara Ranasinghe, additional reporting by Sujata
Rao; editing by Larry King)
 ((Dhara.Ranasinghe@thomsonreuters.com; +442075422684;))

newsTitle: LIVE MARKETS-European equities: Cheap isn't beautiful
body:
* European shares rise
    * Dow clinched new record close
    * Euro rebounds from six-week lows
    * DAX closed for a holiday

    Oct 3 - Welcome to the home for real-time coverage of European equity markets brought to you
by Reuters stocks reporters and anchored today by Helen Reid. Reach her on Messenger to share
your thoughts on market moves: helen.reid.thomsonreuters.com@reuters.net     
 
    
    EUROPEAN EQUITIES: CHEAP ISN'T BEAUTIFUL (1050 GMT)
    How cheap until European shares become irresistible?
    A lot has been said about the divergence between Wall Street's buoyant indexes and Europe's
red-tainted bourses and whether that gap can be filled.
    Noting a "sharp de-rating" of European stocks since January with 12-month forward earnings
falling to 13.8, Florence Chernyak-Bosson, an analyst at Indosuez, wonders whether these low
valuations "could trigger new buy orders, especially from global value funds". 
    She's quick to note though that "cheap does not necessarily imply a bargain" and that
European shares, to get more expensive, need political risk and trade war fears out of the way. 
    And perhaps more crucially than anything else: rising profits translating into earnings
revisions. 
   "At the current juncture, such a combination of positive factors is possible, but not
expected", Chernyak-Bosson writes. 
    She adds that "emerging markets seem better positioned to benefit from renewed investor
interest from a 'value' standpoint, as they remain cheaper than European equities and have
experienced a more marked sell-off in recent months."
    As you can see below, the euro zone is the most seriously unloved region of 2018:
 
    (Julien Ponthus)
    *****
            
    
    REASONS TO BE CHEERFUL ABOUT EUROPEAN STOCKS (1002 GMT)
    There's growing evidence the trade war is hurting global economic activity, and European
stocks remain in thrall of politics, but Barclays analysts still find reasons to be cheerful. 
    "Positioning on Europe appears to be particularly bearish and it is the only region to have
seen net outflows year-to-date," they note, but they see positives outweighing the negatives and
expect "modest upside" into the end of the year. 
    Fundamentals are supportive overall, they maintain. Here are their reasons to be cheerful: 
    * Global growth should be resilient in 2018 at around 4%
    * Earnings revisions are on the right track
    * P/E multiples have fallen 
    * Investors have derisked and sentiment is cautious, but Q4 is typically more positive
    * FX is turning into a support again for the euro zone and UK

    As you can see below, after cyclicals underperformed over Q3, they've started coming back
again as the Citi economic surprise indicator for the euro zone bottomed out. 
    Barclays back cyclical stocks and have a couple of pretty contrarian calls including
overweight financials and autos - but on the big issue of the day, Italy, they remain negative:
"We expect Italy to enter a prolonged period of volatility, which is unlikely to help  European
markets". 
 
    (Helen Reid)
    *****
    
    OPENING SNAPSHOT: ITALIAN RELIEF HELPS EUROPE BOUNCE BACK (0727 GMT)
    Reports that the Italian government aims to lower its budget deficit in 2020 and 2021 from
the 2.4 percent targeted for next year [nI6N1VP01Z] is spreading some optimism among investors,
helping European and Italian stocks rebound after a turbulent start of the week.
    The STOXX 600 <.STOXX> is rising 0.3 percent and Italy's FTSE MIB is bouncing up more than 1
percent and almost all sectors are trading in the black. Activity was reduced by the closure of
the DAX.    
 
    (Danilo Masoni)
    *****
    
    WHAT'S ON THE RADAR: TESCO, ASTON MARTIN, TOPPS TILES (0646 GMT)
    European stocks are set to recover some of the previous day’s losses on Wednesday, with
futures trading up 0.1 to 0.4 percent, and risk appetite could be buoyed by the Dow clinching a
new record close in U.S. trading. 
    Italy will remain a focus for investors and its bank shares could see some relief after bond
yields fell back and the spread to Bunds narrowed thanks to reports the government was targeting
a lower budget deficit in 2020 and 2021. The DAX is closed for a holiday, thinning out trading
across Europe.
    In results Tesco reported a 24.4 percent rise in first-half profit, with results boosted by
the contribution from newly acquired wholesaler Booker and strong summer sales. But this wasn’t
enough to impress markets: the shares are indicated down around 2 percent as the profit figures
missed analysts’ estimates by 5 percent. 
    Also on investors’ radar is the IPO of Aston Martin on the London stock exchange. The luxury
carmaker priced its shares at 19 pounds each, giving it a valuation of $5.6 billion. 
    Surprisingly positive results from UK home improvement retailer Topps Tiles could drive the
shares up 3 to 5 percent, traders say. 
    The firm said it saw full-year profits above market expectations as trading in the fourth
quarter improved. It has been hit hard by consumers reducing big-ticket spending in the past two
years, and the stock is down 56 percent from its pre-Brexit vote levels.
    Tesco profit hit by weak sales in Europe and Asia [nL8N1WJ0T9]
    UK's Topps Tiles sees full-year profit above market expectations [nL4N1WJ17Q]
    Aston Martin priced at 19 pounds per share in float, eyes $5.6 bln valuation [nL8N1WJ0RE]
    UK's ITE sees higher full-year revenue, but warns of adverse currency movements [nL4N1WJ1BV]
    (Helen Reid)
    *****
    
    EUROPEAN FUTURES RISE, LOWER DEFICIT REPORTS BOOST ITALIAN BONDS (0617 GMT)
    European futures have started trading higher though only modestly - up 0.1 to 0.4 percent -
while the DAX is closed for a national holiday, so trading will likely be thinner than usual. 
    Part of the fuel for a rebound today could be reports that Italy's government is targeting a
lower budget deficit in 2020 and 2021. A government source just told us Italy is targeting a

    Italy's Prime Minister Conte is to meet with key ministers over the budget at around 1100

    "Italian budgetary issues are far from over," write Societe Generale analysts.
    "With little on the data or supply front for bond markets to focus on on Wednesday,
political headlines are likely to remain a key driver of the bond market near-term."
    (Helen Reid)

Italy will cut its budget deficit at a faster pace than expected, raising hopes Rome could stave

newsTitle: EU executive to assess Italy's 2019 budget but in context of forecasts for 2020, 2021
body:
BRUSSELS, Oct 3 (Reuters) - The European Commission will
assess Italy's draft budget for 2019 only but do so in the
context of its economic forecasts for growth, debt and deficit
developments for 2020 and 2021, a Commission spokesman said on
Wednesday.
    The Commission said earlier this week that Rome's planned
budget deficit of 2.4 percent of GDP in 2019, 2020 and 2021 was
breaking EU budget rules, because it meant Italy would not be
cutting its structural deficit or huge public debt.
    Rome responded on Wednesday by saying it would keep the
deficit in 2019 at 2.4 but could agree to reduce the gap in 2020
and 2021.
    Asked if the Commission would assess Italy's budget only for
2019 when Rome submits its draft to Brussels on Oct 15th, or
also the deficit plan for 2020 and 2021, the spokesman said the
assessment would concern only 2019.
    He added it would do so in the context of the Commission's
own economic forecasts for 2020 and 2021.

 (Reporting By Jan Strupczewski
Editing by Alissa de Carbonnel)
 ((jan.strupczewski@thomsonreuters.com; +32 2 287 68 37; Reuters
Messaging: jan.strupczewski.reuters.com@reuters.net))

newsTitle: EU officials say Italy compliance with fiscal rules to be assessed against 2019 targets
body:
BRUSSELS, Oct 3 (Reuters) - European Commission's officials
said on Wednesday the EU executive's assessment of Italy's
compliance with fiscal rules will concern only targets for 2019
and not for future years.
    The clarification comes after the Italian government said
earlier on Wednesday it could cut its deficit targets from 2020
after plans announced last week caused market turmoil.
[nL8N1WJ0RJ]

 (Reporting by Francesco Guarascio; editing by Philip
Blenkinsop)
 ((Francesco.Guarascio@thomsonreuters.com; @fraguarascio; +32 2
287 68 17;))

newsTitle: Spain's Supreme court confirms jail sentence for former IMF chief Rato
body:
MADRID, Oct 3 (Reuters) - Spain's Supreme Court on Wednesday
confirmed a four-and-a-half year jail sentence for former
International Monetary Fund (IMF) chief Rodrigo Rato, a judicial
source said.
    Rato was sentenced in 2017 by Spain's High Court for
misusing company credit cards for personal expenses while he
worked at lender Bankia <BKIA.MC>.

 (Reporting By Jesús Aguado
Editing by Julien Toyer)
 ((jesus.aguado@thomsonreuters.com; +34 91 585 8339; Reuters
Messaging: Reuters Messaging:
jesus.aguado.reuters.com@reuters.net))

newsTitle: LIVE MARKETS-Will Brussels accept Rome's budget olive branch?
body:
* European shares rise
    * Dow clinched new record close
    * Euro rebounds from six-week lows
    * DAX closed for a holiday

    Oct 3 - Welcome to the home for real-time coverage of European equity markets brought to you
by Reuters stocks reporters and anchored today by Helen Reid. Reach her on Messenger to share
your thoughts on market moves: helen.reid.thomsonreuters.com@reuters.net     
 
    
    WILL BRUSSELS ACCEPT ROME'S BUDGET OLIVE BRANCH? (1207 GMT)
    Markets are bouncing back today on relief after the Italian government signalled it would
lower its budget deficit target from 2020, appearing to backtrack from initial plans that
spooked investors earlier this week.
    That has fuelled some hopes that Rome could avert a big clash with the EU Commission over
its spending plans but arguably it is still too early to uncork the champagne.
    Some investors are ready to snap up Italian bargains (See UBS' overweight on 2-yr Italian
govvies [nL8N1WJ1CP]) after a sell-off that seems to have gone too far, but a high degree of
caution remains. And that's mirrored in the cash market's thin trading activity.
    A Switzerland-based trader says the problem is that the 2019 deficit target remains at 2.4
percent and that's likely to be a major problem for the EU Commission.
   "It would be surprising if Brussels were to suddenly sound supportive just because the
targets further out have been improved," the trader says.
    And right on cue, an EU official has indeed said: "Targets for 2020 and 2021 are not part of
our assessment". [nL8N1WJ2ZN]
    Of course details of Italy's budget plan may play a big role but it seems we're still not
going to have them today: [nR1N1VZ00U].
    For Alessandro Balsotti, fund manager at JCI Capital in Milan, the key issue for Brussels
will be how Italy is going to pay for fiscal expansion.
    "My impression is that our government is making a risky albeit somewhat rational bet: Europe
could not afford to be with Italy as inflexible as it was with Greece. Italy is not Greece."
    (Danilo Masoni)
    *****
    
    EUROPEAN EQUITIES: CHEAP ISN'T BEAUTIFUL (1050 GMT)
    How cheap until European shares become irresistible?
    A lot has been said about the divergence between Wall Street's buoyant indexes and Europe's
red-tainted bourses and whether that gap can be filled.
    Noting a "sharp de-rating" of European stocks since January with 12-month forward earnings
falling to 13.8, Florence Chernyak-Bosson, an analyst at Indosuez, wonders whether these low
valuations "could trigger new buy orders, especially from global value funds". 
    She's quick to note though that "cheap does not necessarily imply a bargain" and that
European shares, to get more expensive, need political risk and trade war fears out of the way. 
    And perhaps more crucially than anything else: rising profits translating into earnings
revisions. 
   "At the current juncture, such a combination of positive factors is possible, but not
expected", Chernyak-Bosson writes. 
    She adds that "emerging markets seem better positioned to benefit from renewed investor
interest from a 'value' standpoint, as they remain cheaper than European equities and have
experienced a more marked sell-off in recent months."
    As you can see below, the euro zone is the most seriously unloved region of 2018:
 
    (Julien Ponthus)
    *****
            
    
    REASONS TO BE CHEERFUL ABOUT EUROPEAN STOCKS (1002 GMT)
    There's growing evidence the trade war is hurting global economic activity, and European
stocks remain in thrall of politics, but Barclays analysts still find reasons to be cheerful. 
    "Positioning on Europe appears to be particularly bearish and it is the only region to have
seen net outflows year-to-date," they note, but they see positives outweighing the negatives and
expect "modest upside" into the end of the year. 
    Fundamentals are supportive overall, they maintain. Here are their reasons to be cheerful: 
    * Global growth should be resilient in 2018 at around 4%
    * Earnings revisions are on the right track
    * P/E multiples have fallen 
    * Investors have derisked and sentiment is cautious, but Q4 is typically more positive
    * FX is turning into a support again for the euro zone and UK

    As you can see below, after cyclicals underperformed over Q3, they've started coming back
again as the Citi economic surprise indicator for the euro zone bottomed out. 
    Barclays back cyclical stocks and have a couple of pretty contrarian calls including
overweight financials and autos - but on the big issue of the day, Italy, they remain negative:
"We expect Italy to enter a prolonged period of volatility, which is unlikely to help  European
markets". 
 
    (Helen Reid)
    *****
    
    OPENING SNAPSHOT: ITALIAN RELIEF HELPS EUROPE BOUNCE BACK (0727 GMT)
    Reports that the Italian government aims to lower its budget deficit in 2020 and 2021 from
the 2.4 percent targeted for next year [nI6N1VP01Z] is spreading some optimism among investors,
helping European and Italian stocks rebound after a turbulent start of the week.
    The STOXX 600 <.STOXX> is rising 0.3 percent and Italy's FTSE MIB is bouncing up more than 1
percent and almost all sectors are trading in the black. Activity was reduced by the closure of
the DAX.    
 
    (Danilo Masoni)
    *****
    
    WHAT'S ON THE RADAR: TESCO, ASTON MARTIN, TOPPS TILES (0646 GMT)
    European stocks are set to recover some of the previous day’s losses on Wednesday, with
futures trading up 0.1 to 0.4 percent, and risk appetite could be buoyed by the Dow clinching a
new record close in U.S. trading. 
    Italy will remain a focus for investors and its bank shares could see some relief after bond
yields fell back and the spread to Bunds narrowed thanks to reports the government was targeting
a lower budget deficit in 2020 and 2021. The DAX is closed for a holiday, thinning out trading
across Europe.
    In results Tesco reported a 24.4 percent rise in first-half profit, with results boosted by
the contribution from newly acquired wholesaler Booker and strong summer sales. But this wasn’t
enough to impress markets: the shares are indicated down around 2 percent as the profit figures
missed analysts’ estimates by 5 percent. 
    Also on investors’ radar is the IPO of Aston Martin on the London stock exchange. The luxury
carmaker priced its shares at 19 pounds each, giving it a valuation of $5.6 billion. 
    Surprisingly positive results from UK home improvement retailer Topps Tiles could drive the
shares up 3 to 5 percent, traders say. 
    The firm said it saw full-year profits above market expectations as trading in the fourth
quarter improved. It has been hit hard by consumers reducing big-ticket spending in the past two
years, and the stock is down 56 percent from its pre-Brexit vote levels.
    Tesco profit hit by weak sales in Europe and Asia [nL8N1WJ0T9]
    UK's Topps Tiles sees full-year profit above market expectations [nL4N1WJ17Q]
    Aston Martin priced at 19 pounds per share in float, eyes $5.6 bln valuation [nL8N1WJ0RE]
    UK's ITE sees higher full-year revenue, but warns of adverse currency movements [nL4N1WJ1BV]
    (Helen Reid)
    *****
    
    EUROPEAN FUTURES RISE, LOWER DEFICIT REPORTS BOOST ITALIAN BONDS (0617 GMT)
    European futures have started trading higher though only modestly - up 0.1 to 0.4 percent -
while the DAX is closed for a national holiday, so trading will likely be thinner than usual. 
    Part of the fuel for a rebound today could be reports that Italy's government is targeting a
lower budget deficit in 2020 and 2021. A government source just told us Italy is targeting a
budget deficit of 2.2 percent of GDP in 2020 and 2 percent of GDP in 2021, from the expected 2.4
percent next year. [nI6N1VP01Z]
    That's pushed Italian bond yields back down and narrowed the spread with German Bunds -
which will likely boost Italian bank stocks. 
    Italy's Prime Minister Conte is to meet with key ministers over the budget at around 1100
GMT on Wednesday, the source also said.
    "Italian budgetary issues are far from over," write Societe Generale analysts.
    "With little on the data or supply front for bond markets to focus on on Wednesday,
political headlines are likely to remain a key driver of the bond market near-term."
    (Helen Reid)
    ***** 
    
    
    HEADLINES ROUND-UP: PEUGEOT, TELECOM ITALIA, AND TOUGHER POST-BREXIT REGULATION (0549 GMT)
    Peugeot open to new deals as turnaround draws attention -CEO [nL8N1WI5JV]
    Telecom Italia splashes out 2.4 bln euros on 5G spectrum [nL8N1WI65N]
    KPMG expects tougher British financial regime post-Brexit [nL8N1WI4P2]
    French utility EDF served 24-hour strike notice starting Oct. 8 [nL8N1WI6R4]
    BUZZ-WM Morrison: Credit Suisse upgrades to "outperform" [nL4N1WJ0XX]
    Belarus food retailer Eurotorg plans imminent London listing -sources [nL8N1WI5S0]
    "Good chance" Danske whistleblower will testify in European Parliament - lawyer [nL8N1WI1WO]
    ECB's Villeroy says fiscal policy must not influence monetary policy [nL8N1WI59L]
    Big is back: Canada's mega LNG project gets green light on Asia demand [nL4N1WI1FF]
    Spanish government rejects Catalan ultimatum on self-determination [nE8N1UC00I]
    French interior minister resigns in face-off with Macron [nL8N1WI585]
    (Helen Reid)
    *****
    
    MORNING CALL: EUROPEAN STOCKS TO ATTEMPT RECOVERY RALLY (0529 GMT) 
    After a downbeat day yesterday as Italy angst spread, European stocks are expected to open
stronger, buoyed by a new record closing high from the Dow. [nL2N1WI1J7] 
    Asian shares reversed early losses while the euro rebounded from six-week lows on reports
Italy will cut its budget deficit at a faster pace than expected, raising hopes Rome could stave
off a problematic debt blow-out. [nL4N1WJ0KQ]
    Also in political news, a blow for President Macron after interior minister and early ally
Gerard Collomb insisted he wanted to step down despite the president having rejected his
resignation less than 24 hours earlier. [nL8N1WI585]
    Opening calls from LCG are for the FTSE 100 to open 6 points higher at 7,481, the DAX to
open 11 points higher at 12,298, and the CAC 40 to open 8 points higher at 5,475. 
    (Helen Reid)
    *****

newsTitle: UPDATE 1-Spain court confirms jail sentence for former IMF chief Rato
body:
(Adds details)
    MADRID, Oct 3 (Reuters) - Former International Monetary Fund
chief Rodrigo Rato will have to serve a four-and-a-half year
jail sentence for misusing company credit cards when he worked
at state-owned lender Bankia <BKIA.MC>, Spain's Supreme Court
confirmed on Wednesday.
    Rato, who was economy minister in Spain and a prominent
figure in the ruling People's Party (PP) before moving to the
IMF, chaired Bankia for two years until just before its state
bailout in 2012.
    In 2017, the court considered Rato responsible for
overseeing the misuse of credit cards and said he could have
reversed the practice that involved dozens of other executives
and board members of Bankia.
    Rato had appealed the ruling and denied any wrongdoing,
arguing the expenses he accrued on the Bankia credit cards were
legal.
    The case is one of several high-level corruption
investigations now coming to fruition and has been seen as a
test of whether Spain's rich and powerful are accountable before
the law.

 (Reporting By Jesús Aguado
Editing by Julien Toyer and Gareth Jones)
 ((jesus.aguado@thomsonreuters.com; +34 91 585 8339; Reuters
Messaging: Reuters Messaging:
jesus.aguado.reuters.com@reuters.net))

newsTitle: LIVE MARKETS U.S.-Futures point to gains at the open
body:
* Futures point to a higher open
    * European markets snap higher; Italy sees relief rally
    * ADP above estimates

    Oct 3 - Welcome to the home for real-time coverage of U.S.
equity markets brought to you by Reuters stocks reporters and
anchored today by Terence Gabriel. Reach him on Messenger to
share your thoughts on market moves:
terence.gabriel.thomsonreuters.com@reuters.net
    
 
 
 
    
    FUTURES POINT TO GAINS AT THE OPEN (0822 AM EDT/1222 GMT)
    Stock Futures suggest the major averages are poised to gain
at the open.
    This as relief takes hold after Italy indicated that it was
open to reducing its budget deficits in the coming years.
[nL4N1WJ2ES]
    Germany's DAX <.GDAX> is closed for a holiday. That said,
Italy's FTSE MIB <.FTMIB> is rising more than 1 percent.
    Japan <.N225> dipped overnight, while the Shanghai Composite
<.SSEC> is shut for Golden Week.
    Morgan Stanley says a slowdown in auto and industrial end
markets is likely to weigh on Q4 guidance from semiconductor
companies. The firm lowered price targets on eight stocks
including: Microchip Technology <MCHP.O> and Skyworks Solutions
<SWKS.O>. [nL4N1WJ2GC]
    That said, Intel <INTC.O>, which was not included in the
price target cuts, is trading up about 1.5 percent ahead of the
open.
    In terms of data, ADP National Employment came in at 230k
well above the 185k Reuters poll.   
    Here is your pre-market snapshot:
    
 
 
 
    (Terence Gabriel)
    *****

newsTitle: LIVE MARKETS U.S.-Dow Jones Industrial Average: Alone on the dance floor
body:
* Futures point to a higher open
    * European markets snap higher; Italy sees relief rally
    * ADP above estimates

    Oct 3 - Welcome to the home for real-time coverage of U.S.
equity markets brought to you by Reuters stocks reporters and
anchored today by Terence Gabriel. Reach him on Messenger to
share your thoughts on market moves:
terence.gabriel.thomsonreuters.com@reuters.net
    
 
 
 
    DOW JONES INDUSTRIAL AVERAGE: ALONE ON THE DANCE FLOOR (0915
AM EDT/1315 GMT)
    The Dow Jones Industrial Average <.DJI> closed at a fresh
all-time high on Tuesday. That said, in so doing, it lacked
dance partners. Indeed, no other major average was able to tag
along.
    Of 11 other major indices including the S&P 500 <.SPX>,
Nasdaq Composite <.IXIC> and Russell 2000 <.RUT>, not one was
able to confirm the DJI's record high close.
    These other indices find themselves on average about 2.6
percent shy of a record close. The NYSE Composite <.NYA> has yet
to even surpass its January peak, and remains about 4 percent
below that level.
    Even within the DJI itself, only 3 members closed a new
record on Tuesday: Boeing <BA.N>, Apple <AAPL.O> and
UnitedHealth <UNH.N>.
    Nevertheless, if the Dow can extend to channel resistance
derived from a support line off the late-June low, it can still
extend to the 27,000 area. (Click  on chart below)
    An immediate reversal below September's close (26,458.31),
however, can suggest the index is tripping up, and breaking the
Sept. 26 low at 26,349.34 can inflict greater damage.
   
 
 
    (Terence Gabriel)
    *****
    
    
    FUTURES POINT TO GAINS AT THE OPEN (0822 AM EDT/1222 GMT)
    Stock Futures suggest the major averages are poised to gain
at the open.
    This as relief takes hold after Italy indicated that it was

    Japan <.N225> dipped overnight, while the Shanghai Composite

markets is likely to weigh on Q4 guidance from semiconductor

price target cuts, is trading up about 1.5 percent ahead of the
open.
    In terms of data, ADP National Employment came in at 230k
well above the 185k Reuters poll.   
    Here is your pre-market snapshot:

newsTitle: LIVE MARKETS-Afternoon snapshot: STOXX at highs, FTSE too
body:
* European shares rise on Italy relief
    * Euro rebounds from six-week lows
    * DAX closed for a holiday
    * Wall Street to open higher

    Oct 3 - Welcome to the home for real-time coverage of European equity markets brought to you
by Reuters stocks reporters and anchored today by Helen Reid. Reach her on Messenger to share
your thoughts on market moves: helen.reid.thomsonreuters.com@reuters.net     
 
    
    AFTERNOON SNAPSHOT: STOXX AT HIGHS, FTSE TOO (1325 GMT)
    It's plain sailing so far today on European stock markets with the STOXX 600 <.STOXX> moving
to fresh day highs and Italian stocks <.FTMIB> managing to consolidate their bounce after Rome
appeared to soften plans for fiscal expansion. 
    In the UK, PM May has called on her Conservative Party to unite behind her plan to leave the
EU, warning critics their arguments could put Brexit in jeopardy. [nS8N1JB029]
    Net net her speech kept the sterling dipping towards three-week lows, helping the FTSE 100
<.FTSE> climb 0.6 percent to a fresh daily high. [nL8N1WJ39B]
 
    Still in the UK we had earlier on a decent services PMI survey showing the economy appears
to have kept up most of its steady growth in the July-September period. 
    "The latest UK services PMI indicates that the sector remains in a pretty solid state. But
as the perceived risk of a 'no deal' Brexit increases, firms could face a turbulent autumn and
winter," says ING.
    (Danilo Masoni and Julien Ponthus)
    *****
    
    
    WILL BRUSSELS ACCEPT ROME'S BUDGET OLIVE BRANCH? (1207 GMT)

lower its budget deficit target from 2020, appearing to backtrack from initial plans that
spooked investors earlier this week.
    That has fuelled some hopes that Rome could avert a big clash with the EU Commission over
its spending plans but arguably it is still too early to uncork the champagne.
    Some investors are ready to snap up Italian bargains (See UBS' overweight on 2-yr Italian

    For Alessandro Balsotti, fund manager at JCI Capital in Milan, the key issue for Brussels
will be how Italy is going to pay for fiscal expansion.
    "My impression is that our government is making a risky albeit somewhat rational bet: Europe
could not afford to be with Italy as inflexible as it was with Greece. Italy is not Greece."

    *****

experienced a more marked sell-off in recent months."
    As you can see below, the euro zone is the most seriously unloved region of 2018:
 
    (Julien Ponthus)
    *****

    Peugeot open to new deals as turnaround draws attention -CEO [nL8N1WI5JV]

    *****
    
    MORNING CALL: EUROPEAN STOCKS TO ATTEMPT RECOVERY RALLY (0529 GMT) 
    After a downbeat day yesterday as Italy angst spread, European stocks are expected to open
stronger, buoyed by a new record closing high from the Dow. [nL2N1WI1J7] 
    Asian shares reversed early losses while the euro rebounded from six-week lows on reports
Italy will cut its budget deficit at a faster pace than expected, raising hopes Rome could stave
